an4.260:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhadro assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.260:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a fine royal thoroughbred with four factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and reckoned a factor of kingship.

an4.260:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño bhadro assājānīyo vaṇṇasampanno ca hoti, balasampanno ca, javasampanno ca, ārohapariṇāhasampanno ca.
an4.260:1.3.eng: It’s when a fine royal thoroughbred is beautiful, strong, fast, and well-proportioned.

an4.260:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhadro assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.260:1.4.eng: A fine royal thoroughbred with these four factors is worthy of a king. …

an4.260:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an4.260:2.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with four qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an4.260:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vaṇṇasampanno ca hoti, balasampanno ca, javasampanno ca, ārohapariṇāhasampanno ca.
an4.260:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is beautiful, strong, fast, and well proportioned.

an4.260:3.1.eng: And how is a mendicant beautiful?

an4.260:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an4.260:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an4.260:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vaṇṇasampanno hoti.
an4.260:3.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is beautiful.

an4.260:4.1.eng: And how is a mendicant strong?

an4.260:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
an4.260:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an4.260:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu balasampanno hoti.
an4.260:4.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is strong.

an4.260:5.1.eng: And how is a mendicant fast?

an4.260:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an4.260:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an4.260:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu javasampanno hoti.
an4.260:5.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is fast.

an4.260:6.1.eng: And how is a mendicant well proportioned?

an4.260:6.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant receives robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an4.260:6.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ārohapariṇāhasampanno hoti.
an4.260:6.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is well proportioned.

an4.260:7.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an4.260:7.1.eng: A mendicant with these four qualities … is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an4.261:1.3.eng: The powers of energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.262:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu nālaṃ araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevituṃ.
an4.262:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a mendicant has four qualities they’re not ready to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.

an4.262:1.3.pli: Kāmavitakkena, byāpādavitakkena, vihiṃsāvitakkena, duppañño hoti jaḷo elamūgo—
an4.262:1.3.eng: They have sensual, malicious, and cruel thoughts; or they’re witless, dull, and idiotic.

an4.262:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu nālaṃ araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevituṃ.
an4.262:1.4.eng: When a mendicant possesses these four qualities they’re not ready to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.

an4.262:2.1.pli: Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevituṃ.
an4.262:2.1.eng: When a mendicant has four qualities they’re ready to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.

an4.262:2.3.pli: Nekkhammavitakkena, abyāpādavitakkena, avihiṃsāvitakkena, paññavā hoti ajaḷo anelamūgo—
an4.262:2.3.eng: They have thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness; and they’re wise, bright, and clever.

an4.262:2.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevitun”ti.
an4.262:2.4.eng: When a mendicant possesses these four qualities they’re ready to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.”

an4.263:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo viññūnaṃ, bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavati.
an4.263:1.1.eng: “When a foolish, incompetent untrue person has four qualities they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much wickedness.

an4.263:1.3.pli: Sāvajjena kāyakammena, sāvajjena vacīkammena, sāvajjena manokammena, sāvajjāya diṭṭhiyā—
an4.263:1.3.eng: Blameworthy deeds by way of body, speech, and mind, and blameworthy view.

an4.263:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo viññūnaṃ, bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavati.
an4.263:1.4.eng: When a foolish, incompetent untrue person possesses these four qualities they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they create much wickedness.

an4.263:2.1.pli: Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṃ anupahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo viññūnaṃ, bahuñca puññaṃ pasavati.
an4.263:2.1.eng: When an astute, competent true person has four qualities they keep themselves intact and unscathed. They don’t deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much merit.

an4.263:2.3.pli: Anavajjena kāyakammena, anavajjena vacīkammena, anavajjena manokammena, anavajjāya diṭṭhiyā—
an4.263:2.3.eng: Blameless deeds by way of body, speech, and mind, and blameless view.

an4.263:2.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṃ anupahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo viññūnaṃ, bahuñca puññaṃ pasavatī”ti.
an4.263:2.4.eng: When an astute, competent true person possesses these four qualities they keep themselves healthy and whole. They don’t deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they create much merit.”

an4.264:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an4.264:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, someone with four qualities is cast down to hell.

an4.264:1.3.pli: Attanā ca pāṇātipātī hoti, parañca pāṇātipāte samādapeti, pāṇātipāte ca samanuñño hoti, pāṇātipātassa ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—
an4.264:1.3.eng: They themselves kill living creatures; they encourage others to kill living creatures; they approve of killing living creatures; and they praise killing living creatures.

an4.264:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an4.264:1.4.eng: Someone with these four qualities is cast down to hell.

an4.264:2.1.pli: Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge.
an4.264:2.1.eng: Someone with four qualities is raised up to heaven.

an4.264:2.3.pli: Attanā ca pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, parañca pāṇātipātā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, pāṇātipātā veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti, pāṇātipātā veramaṇiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—
an4.264:2.3.eng: They don’t themselves kill living creatures; they encourage others to not kill living creatures; they approve of not killing living creatures; and they praise not killing living creatures.

an4.264:2.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge”ti.
an4.264:2.4.eng: Someone with these four qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an4.265:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an4.265:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, someone with four qualities is cast down to hell.

an4.265:1.3.pli: Attanā ca adinnādāyī hoti, parañca adinnādāne samādapeti, adinnādāne ca samanuñño hoti, adinnādānassa ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—

an4.265:1.4.eng: Someone with four qualities is raised up to heaven. …

an4.265:2.1.pli: Attanā ca adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, parañca adinnādānā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, adinnādānā veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti, adinnādānā veramaṇiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi kho, bhikkhave …pe….

an4.266:1.1.pli: …pe… Attanā ca kāmesumicchācārī hoti, parañca kāmesumicchācāre samādapeti, kāmesumicchācāre ca samanuñño hoti, kāmesumicchācārassa ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi kho …pe….

an4.266:2.1.pli: Attanā ca kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, parañca kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi kho …pe….
an4.266:2.1.eng: They themselves don’t commit sexual misconduct …”

an4.267:1.1.pli: …pe… Attanā ca musāvādī hoti, parañca musāvāde samādapeti, musāvāde ca samanuñño hoti, musāvādassa ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi kho …pe….

an4.267:2.1.pli: Attanā ca musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, parañca musāvādā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, musāvādā veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti, musāvādā veramaṇiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi …pe….

an4.268:1.1.pli: …pe… Attanā ca pisuṇavāco hoti, parañca pisuṇāya vācāya samādapeti, pisuṇāya vācāya ca samanuñño hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi …pe….

an4.268:2.1.pli: Attanā ca pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, parañca pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇiyā samādapeti, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi …pe….

an4.269:1.1.pli: …pe… Attanā ca pharusavāco hoti, parañca pharusāya vācāya samādapeti, pharusāya vācāya ca samanuñño hoti, pharusāya vācāya ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati …pe….

an4.269:2.1.pli: Attanā ca pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, parañca pharusāya vācāya veramaṇiyā samādapeti, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi kho …pe….

an4.27:1.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, appāni ca sulabhāni ca, tāni ca anavajjāni.
an4.27:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four trifles are easy to find and are blameless.

an4.27:1.3.pli: Paṃsukūlaṃ, bhikkhave, cīvarānaṃ appañca sulabhañca, tañca anavajjaṃ.

an4.27:1.4.pli: Piṇḍiyālopo, bhikkhave, bhojanānaṃ appañca sulabhañca, tañca anavajjaṃ.

an4.27:1.5.pli: Rukkhamūlaṃ, bhikkhave, senāsanānaṃ appañca sulabhañca, tañca anavajjaṃ.
an4.27:1.5.eng: Lodgings at the root of a tree …

an4.27:1.6.pli: Pūtimuttaṃ, bhikkhave, bhesajjānaṃ appañca sulabhañca, tañca anavajjaṃ.

an4.27:1.7.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri appāni ca sulabhāni ca, tāni ca anavajjāni.
an4.27:1.7.eng: These four trifles are easy to find and are blameless.

an4.27:1.8.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu appena ca tuṭṭho hoti sulabhena ca, idamassāhaṃ aññataraṃ sāmaññaṅganti vadāmīti.
an4.27:1.8.eng: When a mendicant is content with trifles that are easy to find, they have one of the factors of the ascetic life, I say.

an4.27:2.1.eng: When you’re content with what’s blameless,

an4.27:3.1.eng: These qualities are said to be

an4.27:3.3.eng: They’re mastered by one who trains,

an4.270:1.1.pli: …pe… Attanā ca samphappalāpī hoti, parañca samphappalāpe samādapeti, samphappalāpe ca samanuñño hoti, samphappalāpassa ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi …pe….

an4.270:2.1.pli: Attanā ca samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti, parañca samphappalāpā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, samphappalāpā veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti, samphappalāpā veramaṇiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi kho, bhikkhave …pe….

an4.271:1.1.pli: …pe… Attanā ca abhijjhālu hoti, parañca abhijjhāya samādapeti, abhijjhāya ca samanuñño hoti, abhijjhāya ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati …pe….

an4.271:2.1.pli: Attanā ca anabhijjhālu hoti, parañca anabhijjhāya samādapeti, anabhijjhāya ca samanuñño hoti, anabhijjhāya ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi kho …pe….

an4.272:1.1.pli: …pe… Attanā ca byāpannacitto hoti, parañca byāpāde samādapeti, byāpāde ca samanuñño hoti, byāpādassa ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi …pe….

an4.272:2.1.pli: Attanā ca abyāpannacitto hoti, parañca abyāpāde samādapeti, abyāpāde ca samanuñño hoti, abyāpādassa ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi …pe….

an4.273:1.1.pli: …pe… Attanā ca micchādiṭṭhiko hoti, parañca micchādiṭṭhiyā samādapeti, micchādiṭṭhiyā ca samanuñño hoti, micchādiṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—imehi …pe….

an4.273:2.1.pli: Attanā ca sammādiṭṭhiko hoti, parañca sammādiṭṭhiyā samādapeti, sammādiṭṭhiyā ca samanuñño hoti, sammādiṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati—
an4.273:2.1.eng: They themselves have right view; they encourage others to have right view; they approve of right view; and they praise right view.

an4.273:2.2.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ saggeti.
an4.273:2.2.eng: Someone with these four qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an4.274:1.1.eng: “For insight into greed, four things should be developed.

an4.274:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
an4.274:1.3.eng: Firstly, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

an4.274:1.4.pli: vedanāsu …pe… citte …pe… dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
an4.274:1.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings … mind … principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

an4.274:1.5.pli: Rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an4.274:1.5.eng: For insight into greed, these four things should be developed.”

an4.275:1.1.eng: “For insight into greed, four things should be developed.

an4.275:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
an4.275:1.3.eng: Firstly, a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.

an4.275:1.4.pli: uppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya …pe… anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya …pe… uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
an4.275:1.4.eng: …so that unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up … so that skillful qualities arise … so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are fulfilled by development.

an4.275:1.5.pli: Rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an4.275:1.5.eng: For insight into greed, these four things should be developed.”

an4.276:1.1.eng: “For insight into greed, four things should be developed.

an4.276:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti;
an4.276:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.

an4.276:1.4.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy …

an4.276:1.7.pli: Rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an4.276:1.7.eng: For insight into greed, these four things should be developed.”

an4.277-303:1.1.pli: “Rāgassa, bhikkhave, pariññāya …pe… parikkhayāya … pahānāya … khayāya … vayāya … virāgāya … nirodhāya … cāgāya … paṭinissaggāya cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā …pe….
an4.277-303:1.1.eng: “For the complete understanding … finishing … giving up … ending … vanishing … fading away … cessation … giving away … letting go of greed, four things should be developed.”

an4.28:1.1.pli: “Cattārome, bhikkhave, ariyavaṃsā aggaññā rattaññā vaṃsaññā porāṇā asaṅkiṇṇā asaṅkiṇṇapubbā, na saṅkīyanti na saṅkīyissanti, appaṭikuṭṭhā samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an4.28:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four noble traditions are primordial, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. They are uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now, nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.

an4.28:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena cīvarena, itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, na ca cīvarahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjati, aladdhā ca cīvaraṃ na paritassati, laddhā ca cīvaraṃ agadhito amucchito anajjhosanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati;
an4.28:1.3.eng: Firstly, a mendicant is content with any kind of robe, and praises such contentment. They don’t employ improper solicitation for the sake of a robe. They don’t worry if they don’t get a robe. And if they do get a robe, they use it untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.

an4.28:1.4.pli: tāya ca pana itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā nevattānukkaṃseti, no paraṃ vambheti.
an4.28:1.4.eng: But they don’t glorify themselves or put others down on account of their contentment.

an4.28:1.5.pli: Yo hi tattha dakkho analaso sampajāno patissato, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu porāṇe aggaññe ariyavaṃse ṭhito.
an4.28:1.5.eng: A mendicant who is deft, tireless, aware, and mindful in this is said to stand in the ancient, primordial noble tradition.

an4.28:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena piṇḍapātena, itarītarapiṇḍapātasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, na ca piṇḍapātahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjati, aladdhā ca piṇḍapātaṃ na paritassati, laddhā ca piṇḍapātaṃ agadhito amucchito anajjhosanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati;
an4.28:2.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of almsfood …

an4.28:2.2.pli: tāya ca pana itarītarapiṇḍapātasantuṭṭhiyā nevattānukkaṃseti, no paraṃ vambheti.

an4.28:2.3.pli: Yo hi tattha dakkho analaso sampajāno patissato, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu porāṇe aggaññe ariyavaṃse ṭhito.

an4.28:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena senāsanena, itarītarasenāsanasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, na ca senāsanahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjati, aladdhā ca senāsanaṃ na paritassati, laddhā ca senāsanaṃ agadhito amucchito anajjhosanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati;
an4.28:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of lodgings …

an4.28:3.2.pli: tāya ca pana itarītarasenāsanasantuṭṭhiyā nevattānukkaṃseti, no paraṃ vambheti.

an4.28:3.3.pli: Yo hi tattha dakkho analaso sampajāno patissato, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu porāṇe aggaññe ariyavaṃse ṭhito.

an4.28:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bhāvanārāmo hoti bhāvanārato, pahānārāmo hoti pahānarato;
an4.28:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant enjoys meditation and loves to meditate. They enjoy giving up and love to give up.

an4.28:4.2.pli: tāya ca pana bhāvanārāmatāya bhāvanāratiyā pahānārāmatāya pahānaratiyā nevattānukkaṃseti, no paraṃ vambheti.
an4.28:4.2.eng: But they don’t glorify themselves or put down others on account of their love for meditation and giving up.

an4.28:4.3.pli: Yo hi tattha dakkho analaso sampajāno patissato, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu porāṇe aggaññe ariyavaṃse ṭhito.
an4.28:4.3.eng: A mendicant who is deft, tireless, aware, and mindful in this is said to stand in the ancient, primordial noble tradition.

an4.28:4.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro ariyavaṃsā aggaññā rattaññā vaṃsaññā porāṇā asaṅkiṇṇā asaṅkiṇṇapubbā, na saṅkīyanti na saṅkīyissanti, appaṭikuṭṭhā samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an4.28:4.4.eng: These four noble traditions are primordial, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. They are uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.

an4.28:5.1.pli: Imehi ca pana, bhikkhave, catūhi ariyavaṃsehi samannāgato bhikkhu puratthimāya cepi disāya viharati sveva aratiṃ sahati, na taṃ arati sahati;
an4.28:5.1.eng: When a mendicant possesses these four noble traditions, if they live in the east they prevail over discontent, and discontent doesn’t prevail over them.

an4.28:5.2.pli: pacchimāya cepi disāya viharati sveva aratiṃ sahati, na taṃ arati sahati;
an4.28:5.2.eng: If they live in the west …

an4.28:5.3.pli: uttarāya cepi disāya viharati sveva aratiṃ sahati, na taṃ arati sahati;

an4.28:5.4.pli: dakkhiṇāya cepi disāya viharati sveva aratiṃ sahati, na taṃ arati sahati.
an4.28:5.4.eng: the south, they prevail over discontent, and discontent doesn’t prevail over them.

an4.28:5.6.eng: Because the attentive prevail over desire and discontent.

an4.28:6.1.eng: Discontent cannot prevail over the attentive;

an4.28:6.2.eng: the attentive are not prevailed over by discontent.

an4.28:6.3.eng: The attentive can prevail over discontent,

an4.28:6.4.eng: for the attentive are those who prevail over discontent.

an4.28:7.1.eng: Who can hold back the dispeller,

an4.28:7.3.eng: Like a pendant of Black Plum River gold,

an4.28:7.4.eng: who is worthy to criticize them?

an4.28:7.6.eng: and by the Divinity, too, they’re praised.”

an4.29:1.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, dhammapadāni aggaññāni rattaññāni vaṃsaññāni porāṇāni asaṅkiṇṇāni asaṅkiṇṇapubbāni, na saṅkīyanti na saṅkīyissanti, appaṭikuṭṭhāni samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an4.29:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four footprints of the Dhamma are primordial, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. They are uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.

an4.29:1.3.pli: Anabhijjhā, bhikkhave, dhammapadaṃ aggaññaṃ rattaññaṃ vaṃsaññaṃ porāṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇapubbaṃ, na saṅkīyati na saṅkīyissati, appaṭikuṭṭhaṃ samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an4.29:1.3.eng: Contentment, good will, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

an4.29:2.1.pli: Abyāpādo, bhikkhave, dhammapadaṃ aggaññaṃ rattaññaṃ vaṃsaññaṃ porāṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇapubbaṃ, na saṅkīyati na saṅkīyissati, appaṭikuṭṭhaṃ samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.

an4.29:3.1.pli: Sammāsati, bhikkhave, dhammapadaṃ aggaññaṃ rattaññaṃ vaṃsaññaṃ porāṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇapubbaṃ, na saṅkīyati na saṅkīyissati, appaṭikuṭṭhaṃ samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.

an4.29:4.1.pli: Sammāsamādhi, bhikkhave, dhammapadaṃ aggaññaṃ rattaññaṃ vaṃsaññaṃ porāṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇapubbaṃ, na saṅkīyati na saṅkīyissati, appaṭikuṭṭhaṃ samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.

an4.29:4.2.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri dhammapadāni aggaññāni rattaññāni vaṃsaññāni porāṇāni asaṅkiṇṇāni asaṅkiṇṇapubbāni, na saṅkīyanti na saṅkīyissanti, appaṭikuṭṭhāni samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhīti.
an4.29:4.2.eng: These four footprints of the Dhamma are primordial, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. They are uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.

an4.29:5.2.eng: and a heart of good will,
